'''L.V. Banks''' (October 28, 1932 – May 2, 2011)<ref name="Bluesman">{{cite web |url=http://bluesman2001.blogspot.com/2011/05/lv-banks-rip.html |title=L.V. Banks RIP |author=Bob Corritore |date=May 29, 2011 |work= |publisher=Bluesman2001.blogspot.com |accessdate=December 17, 2011}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[soul blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter. He was a respected club performer in Chicago for many years, before recording two albums for Wolf Records.

==Life and career==
Banks was born in [[Stringtown, Mississippi|Stringtown]], [[Mississippi]].<ref name="Hanson"/><ref name="Albums"/> He taught himself to play the guitar and [[frontman|fronted]] his own blues band in [[Greenville, Mississippi]]. His musical influences came from [[B.B. King]], [[Howlin' Wolf]], and [[Little Milton]].<ref name="Jazz">{{cite web |url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=5396 |title=L.V. Banks: ''Ruby'' |author=Ed Kopp |date=April 1, 2000 |work= |publisher=Allaboutjazz.com |accessdate=December 17, 2011}}</ref> Banks had moved to [[St. Louis, Missouri]],<ref name="Bluesman"/> before he was [[Conscription in the United States|drafted]] to the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]], and after his duty was over, in the early 1960s he relocated to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]].<ref name="Hanson">{{cite book
| first= Karen
| last= Hanson
| year= 2007
| title= Today's Chicago Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Lake Claremont Press
| location= Chicago
| page= 122
| isbn= 978-1-893121-19-5}}</ref> He played on [[Maxwell Street]], and later was a regular fixture for over three decades in local [[nightclub|clubs]], particularly on the [[South Side, Chicago|South Side]].<ref name="Bluesman"/><ref name="Hanson"/> In the early 1990s, Banks acted as mentor to the then teenaged blues musician, [[Marty Sammon]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://g-freethoughts.blogspot.com/2011/05/lv-banks-bluesman-rest-in-peace.html |title=L.V. Banks, Bluesman - Rest in Peace|author= |date= |work= |publisher=G-freethoughts.blogspot.com |accessdate=December 17, 2011}}</ref>

Banks debut [[album]] was ''Let Me Be Your Teddy Bear'', which was released in June 1998 on the [[Austria]]n based [[record label]], Wolf. [[John Primer]] played guitar on the album.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=let-me-be-your-teddy-bear-r366540/credits|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Let Me Be Your Teddy Bear'' > Credits |accessdate=December 17, 2011 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> Banks' follow-up and final album release was titled  ''Ruby'' (2000, Wolf).<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=ruby-r464891/credits|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Ruby'' > Credits |accessdate=December 17, 2011 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>

He died of [[heart failure]] in the South Shore Hospital, Chicago in May 2011, aged 78. His son, Tre', is following his father's tradition as a Chicago based blues musician.<ref name="Bluesman"/>
